item.title: Metals Mixed as Base Metals Rise, Gold Slips
item.description: Base metals prices rose, while gold remained under pressure on worries of further Fed rate hikes.

item.title: Oil Rises on Tightening Supply
item.description: Oil prices pushed higher as tightening fundamentals continued to support key benchmarks, and ING said investors will look to OPEC+ Joint Ministerial Monitoring Committee on Wednesday to see if there are signs of a change in its output policy.

item.title: Dollar Edges Lower, But Falls Don't Look Convincing
item.description: The dollar was slightly lower, but the falls aren’t convincing enough to look like they could mark the start of a downward trend, UniCredit Research said.

item.title: Allianz Names New CFO; Renews CEO Mandate
item.description: Allianz appointed Claire-Marie Coste-Lepoutre as CFO, replacing Giulio Terzariol, and renewed the mandate of CEO Oliver Baete until 2028.

item.title: United Utilities Outlines Five-Year Investment Plan
item.description: United Utilities set out plans to invest £13.7 billion in its waste and wastewater infrastructure between, 2025 and 2030, creating new jobs.

item.title: Gavin Newsom Appoints Laphonza Butler to Fill Dianne Feinstein's Senate Seat
item.description: Butler, previously a labor leader in California, is currently president of Emily’s List.

item.title: BAE Systems Wins Nuclear Submarine Contract From U.K. Government
item.description: BAE Systems has been awarded £3.95 billion by the U.K. government for the next phase of its nuclear-powered attack submarine program, part of a security pact between the U.S., U.K. and Australia.

item.title: Singapore Property Prices Rose Marginally in Third Quarter
item.description: Property prices in Singapore rose slightly in the third quarter, but there were signs that the market has peaked.

item.title: Australia Shares Close 0.2% Lower Ahead of RBA Meeting
item.description: Australia’s S&P/ASX 200 index closed 0.2% lower at 7033.2 ahead of the first meeting of the country’s central bank under its new governor.

item.title: China's Economy Likely to Slow as Headwinds Persist, World Bank Says
item.description: The Chinese economy is likely to slow next year due to continued domestic headwinds, the World Bank said in a report, cutting its growth projection for the country.

item.title: How Ukraine Tricks Russia Into Wasting Ammunition
item.description: Technological advances have made battlefield deception harder but more important than ever.

item.title: China Dominates the Global Lithium Industry. Can the U.S. Ever Catch Up?
item.description: China controls 55% of the lithium processing market. Now, the U.S. is making its own domestic investments to try to secure its own supply in a race for supply chain independence.

item.title: Bill Ackman's Pershing Square received regulatory signoff for a novel investment vehicle, which he said he would consider for a transaction with X, formerly Twitter.
item.description: Bill Ackman’s Pershing Square received regulatory signoff for a novel investment vehicle, which he said he would consider for a transaction with X, formerly Twitter.

item.title: September passed with little news about Tesla starting deliveries of its long-delayed Cybertruck, after CEO Elon Musk had stoked hopes of its arrival in the third quarter.
item.description: September passed with little news about Tesla starting deliveries of its long-delayed Cybertruck, after CEO Elon Musk had stoked hopes of its arrival in the third quarter.

item.title: Trump begins a monthslong courtroom battle in New York this week that could cost him several hundred million dollars in penalties and deal a blow to the business-titan persona on which he built his political identity.
item.description: Trump begins a monthslong courtroom battle in New York this week that could cost him several hundred million dollars in penalties and deal a blow to the business-titan persona on which he built his political identity.

item.title: Small-business bankruptcy filings are rising this year, a signal that higher interest rates, tighter lending standards and greater operating costs are straining entrepreneurs.
item.description: Small-business bankruptcy filings are rising this year, a signal that higher interest rates, tighter lending standards and greater operating costs are straining entrepreneurs.

item.title: U.S. officials sought to defuse rising tensions in the Balkans, as a surge in violence there pushed NATO to boost its presence in the area and threatened to trigger a broader conflict between Serbia and Kosovo.
item.description: U.S. officials sought to defuse rising tensions in the Balkans, as a surge in violence there pushed NATO to boost its presence in the area and threatened to trigger a broader conflict between Serbia and Kosovo.

item.title: The labor union for West Coast dockworkers filed for bankruptcy to fend off a judgment holding it liable for what a federal jury found to be illegal slowdowns and work stoppages at the Port of Portland in Oregon.
item.description: The labor union for West Coast dockworkers filed for bankruptcy to fend off a judgment holding it liable for what a federal jury found to be illegal slowdowns and work stoppages at the Port of Portland in Oregon.

item.title: The Supreme Court returns to the bench Monday for a term that conservative activists hope will bring new constraints on federal power, from the regulation of financial institutions to environmental protection to which revenue sources Congress can tap to replenish the Treasury.
item.description: The Supreme Court returns to the bench Monday for a term that conservative activists hope will bring new constraints on federal power, from the regulation of financial institutions to environmental protection to which revenue sources Congress can tap to replenish the Treasury.

item.title: PG&E chief Patti Poppe is fighting to salvage a plan to bury power lines to reduce wildfire risk weeks before regulators are expected to decide to significantly restrict the number of underground lines in favor of other, cheaper, ways of mitigating the danger.
item.description: PG&E chief Patti Poppe is fighting to salvage a plan to bury power lines to reduce wildfire risk weeks before regulators are expected to decide to significantly restrict the number of underground lines in favor of other, cheaper, ways of mitigating the danger.
